notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 30, 2020: Room changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: With the completion of the human genome sequence, we now have access to more information than ever before about our genetic make-up. This course addresses topics such as what are genes, how are they identified and how does knowledge about genes impact society. Students will learn basic concepts in genetics. Using this conceptual foundation, the significance of genomic research for understanding human biology, and the social consequences that may result from it, will be discussed. Evaluation is based on class discussions, homework, oral presentation and written assignments. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Genes, Genomes and Us

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course allows students to broaden their knowledge about the most important human viruses and prions. In essence, what viruses are, what they do, what are the diseases caused by viruses and how they are transmitted, etc., and what can be done about them (vaccines, antiviral treatments, etc.). Viruses cause many diseases ranging from a benign rash to severe hemorrhages and death. Each student will select a specific topic in Virology and write an essay and present a seminar for the rest of the class. Major "hot" problems in Virology from pandemics to controversial vaccines will also be discussed. Two tests covering all materials presented by all the students' seminars will be conducted. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Viruses

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will be online synchronous. Lectures will be recorded and available to students. Since this is a seminar course, students (one or two) a week become live presenters (synchronous). All presentations will be recorded and available to students.

cmCourseInfo.description: From the manipulation of genes of plants for improved food production through to human tissue engineering and stem cell research, biotechnology is increasingly playing a major role in our world. Society, however, is often challenged by the rapid advances in our knowledge in these areas, and how to best apply these technologies in a manner that is socially responsible and economically viable. In this seminar course, students will research and describe various applications of biotechnology using information obtained from reputable sources, and lead discussions on the benefits and concerns that arise from this research. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biotechnology and Society

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

cmCourseInfo.description: An online course intended to provide non-science students with an understanding of basic concepts in molecular biology and genetics, with particular emphasis on humans. Students will work online in groups on problem sets. The course will end with an introduction to biotechnology, including an opportunity for students to use their new knowledge to explore a real, multi-dimensional problem (e.g., cancer). Lectures will be delivered via the web and mandatory tutorials will require live webinar participation. The final exam will require attendance on the St. George campus. This course does not count towards CSB programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Biology, Biotechnology and You

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Lectures:  Online Asynchronous

The course instructor will provide details.

Tutorials:  Online Synchronous

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

Delivery Instructions

The lectures of this course are online asynchronous and the tutorials are online synchronous. 

Students must be able to access lecture videos on YouTube. Students also need: 

• Personal Computer: You will need regular access to a computer – preferably a personal computer – with administrator privileges and you should be comfortable managing software and hardware. While much can be done with tablets, smartphones and other mobile devices they are not guaranteed to work in all areas of the course. For an optimal experience you must have a laptop or desktop computer (Windows 10 or higher or Mac OS X 10.14 or higher is recommended). 

• Internet connection: High speed broadband access (LAN, Cable or DSL) is highly recommended for an optimal learning experience. A Web Browser is required for access to Quercus. In some instances, it may be necessary for some users to upgrade their web browser programs. A list of supported browsers can be found at https://community.canvaslms.com/docs/DOC-10461-supported-web-browsers (Links to an external site.) 

• Speaker and Headphones: Many courses will have synchronous (live) online meetings using webinar software (Links to an external site.). It is preferable to use headphones with an attached microphone for synchronous (live) sessions. • Software: Word processing software will be required (If you do not already have this, Office 365 ProPlus can be found at https://onesearch.library.utoronto.ca/ic-faq-categories/office-365-proplus (Links to an external site).

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides non-science students with an additional opportunity to explore biotechnology and its applications in agriculture, the environment, and human health including: genetically modified organisms, drug discovery and aging. Most lectures are viewed online before class and students work in groups during class on problem sets and case studies designed to stimulate further learning, enhance evidence-based reasoning, and promote reflection on the role of biotechnology in society. This course does not count towards CSB programs. CSB201H1 is not a prerequisite for this course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Further Exploration in Biotechnology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

 

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously, but class/lecture attendance is mandatory. Tutorials (during the times indicated on the FAS timetable; mandatory) will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times.

 

Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class (tutorial) meetings.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project.  The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student.  The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components).  In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

cmCourseInfo.description: The regulation of physiological processes by hormones and other signalling molecules in non-human chordates. An integrated genes-to-environment approach is used to examine aspects of hormonal evolution, physiological information flow, behaviour and neuroendocrinology, and xenobiotic endocrine disruptors. Students will have the opportunity to research areas of their own interest via group interaction in a series of tutorial sessions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Endocrine Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Tutorial enrolment can be done on ACORN until Friday, September 11th at 4pm. Late tutorial enrolment or changes must be done in the CSB325H1 Office (RW424E) after this date.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures:  Online Synchronous

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. Lectures will be available online at the beginning of the course. Each week the instructor will provide an online forum to review the material and for students to ask questions regarding the course material.  In-person appointments can be provided if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

Tutorials:  Online Synchronous

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

courses.name: Extracellular Matrix Dynamics and Associated Pathologies

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the expression, structure and function of the four major classes of ECM macromolecules: collagen, proteoglycans, non-collagenous structural proteins and glycoproteins. In addition to forming elaborate networks that give tissues and organs their unique architectural design and biomechanical properties, ECM molecules act as potent regulators of all cellular activities. Emphasis is placed on the morphoregulatory contribution(s) of ECM molecules to normal and pathological development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Extracellular Matrix Dynamics and Associated Pathologies

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course will be presented online-synchronous.

The lectures will be recorded and will be available for students to view asynchronously post-lecture.  Powerpoint lectures and pre-recorded videos will be made available on the day before the lectures.  No special aids are required.  A chat line will be maintained by teaching assistants (TAs) during and 30 minutes post-lecture. At regular intervals during the lecture, questions posted on the chat line will be answered. The TAs will also be available at designated times to answers students’ questions.

cmCourseInfo.description: Basic concepts in developmental biology. Early development of invertebrates and vertebrates will be discussed with emphasis on experimental and molecular analysis of developmental mechanisms. Tutorials focus on the experimental analysis of embryonic development and regeneration, and discuss primary literature of selected topics in developmental biology. (Lab Materials Fee: $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: Developmental Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The CSB328 Monday lectures will delivered on-line synchronously while the Thursday lectures will be delivered asynchronously. Recordings of synchronous lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously but students are encouraged to attend and participate on line in those lectures at the time they are given. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous and in person at their scheduled times.

courses.name: Stem Cell Biology: Developmental Models and Cell-based Therapeutics

cmCourseInfo.description: Stem cells provide the basis for cellular diversity in multicellular organisms and have enormous therapeutic potential in regenerative medicine. The course will introduce students to the differences and similarities between stem cells from different organisms, their roles throughout development and therapeutic potential.
cmCourseInfo.title: Stem Cell Biology: Developmental Models and Cell-based Therapeutics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone in order to participate in online activities. The course instructor will provide further details.

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory course on molecular and cell biology research techniques used to study genes and proteins. Topics include plasmid cloning, PCR, bioinformatics, gene expression analyses, protein-protein interactions, and protein subcellular localization. (Lab Materials Fee: $50).
cmCourseInfo.title: Techniques in Molecular and Cell Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. The course instructors will provide detailed schedules through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: The development of multicellular organisms is dependent on complex cell-cell and cell-matrix dynamics. The course examines the molecules and mechanisms involved and how they act in concert to regulate distinct developmental and physiological events. Emphasis is placed on the experimental approaches and technology used to study the molecular interactions and dynamics that alter structure-function relationships in cells and organisms.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Cell Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

 

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials (during the times indicated on the FAS timetable; mandatory) will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times.

 

Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class (tutorial) meetings.

cmCourseInfo.description: Plant developmental genetics at the molecular, cellular and organismal level, generation and use of genomic resourses in plant model organisms. Questions address the genetic dissection of plant embryo and meristem development, plant stem cell specification and tissue patterning. Genomic approaches applicable to plant biotechnology are also covered.
cmCourseInfo.title: Plant Development
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO230H1/BIO255H1, BIO260H1/(HMB265H1 with a minimum grade of 73%)

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be available online-synchronous at their scheduled times, and recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Animal structure and function, at all levels from molecule to whole animal, are dependent on energy. This course describes how the supply, consumption, transformation, exchange and storage of energy can facilitate, constrain and limit animal function. Emphasis is placed on systems level physiological function and whole animal performance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Animal Energetics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course will be available only as online synchronous with no recording. Students must have the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) and Quercus. It is strongly recommended to use a stable lined high speed broadband internet connection to prevent disconnection. The course instructor will provide details.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how the central and peripheral nervous system controls breathing in mammals. Topics include how the brain generates rhythmic breathing movements, how sleep impacts breathing control and how abnormal breathing contributes to disorders such as sleep apnea.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurobiology of Respiration

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.  Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

notes.name: Section Note

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory exercises will include traditional and guided inquiry approaches to investigate and gain an understanding of the regulation of physiological systems in vertebrates and invertebrates. Students will experience the nature of physiological investigation while being exposed to a range of the current experimental approaches animal physiologists use to design, test and evaluate hypotheses, and communicate their findings. This course will emphasize the fundamental characteristics humans share with all animal life and the physiological adaptations that have permitted species to exploit alternative environmental niches. This course requires participation and includes group work, written assignments, and oral presentations. (Lab Materials Fee: $50). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: Laboratory in Comparative Animal Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be delivered in person per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: Genome structure and the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotic cells. Topics include gene duplication, repetitive DNA, transcription, gene silencing and regulation, expression profiling, and nuclear reprogramming. Tutorials emphasize problem based learning exercises that relate to recent advances in the broad field of eukaryotic gene expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Eukaryotic Gene Expression

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory methods used in plant molecular biology research. Topics include vector construction, plant transformations, PCR, DNA blots, high-throughput screens, genetic mapping, and bioinformatic analyses. (Lab Materials Fee: $50). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: Laboratory in Molecular Plant Biology
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: BIO251H1 or higher level plant biology course; BCH311H1/CSB349H1/MGY311Y1 concurrently

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to basic and medical virology. What you should know about viruses and the diseases they cause. Tutorials are optional.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Virology

cmCourseInfo.description: Use of available programs for analyzing biological data. This is an introductory course with a strong emphasis on hands-on methods. Some theory is introduced, but the main focus is on using extant bioinformatics tools to analyze data and generate biological hypotheses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bioinformatic Methods

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In-class activities, including pre-lab talk and practicals of the course, will be available only as online synchronous via Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) with no recording. Students must have the ability to access and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra), Quercus and Coursera. Students must be able to attend classes live via Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) and write quizzes on Quercus during scheduled times (Eastern Standard Time) with stable internet connections. It is strongly recommended to have multiple different routes/sources of lined high speed broadband internet connection in order to prevent disconnections. The course instructor will provide details.

cmCourseInfo.description: Plants have co-evolved with microbes ever since their first appearance on land, resulting in sophisticated strategies of pathogenicity, symbiosis, commensalisms and mutualism. This course presents an overview of these strategies with examples of bacteria, fungi, oomycetes and viruses that have evolved intimate associations with plants, and discusses plant immune systems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Plant-Microorganism Interactions and Plant Immunity

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project.  The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student.  The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components).  In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

cmCourseInfo.description: Students will gain an integrated understanding of how organismal and cellular stress affects the process of reproduction. The focus will be primarily on chordates and will examine genetic, cellular, organismal, behavioural, and social levels of interaction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physiology of Stress and Reproduction

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

courses.name: Drosophila as a Model in Cancer Research

cmCourseInfo.description: Use of the genetic model organism Drosophila in biomedical research with specific emphasis on cancer research. Students will read, discuss and present classical papers and current literature in the field to enhance their ability to critically evaluate the primary scientific literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: Drosophila as a Model in Cancer Research

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course has three components: Lectures, discussions, and students seminars. Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Discussions and students seminars will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is essential that students have access to a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The cytoskeleton is a highly dynamic protein network that links all regions and components of the cell to provide a structural framework for organizing numerous cellular activities. This course will explore the molecular regulation of the actin and microtubule cytoskeletons during cell migration and other cellular processes. Topics will include (1) an overview of key regulators of the cytoskeleton, (2) how they organize specific cellular structures, and (3) how the coordinated activities of cytoskeletal networks govern complex cellular behaviours. The format of this course is mainly journal club style presentations and student-led discussions of research papers, together with supporting background lectures. Experience with critical evaluation of research papers is emphasized.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cytoskeletal Networks of the Cell
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum grade of 73% in BCH311H1/CSB349H1/MGY311Y1, minimum grade of 73% in BCH340H1/CJH332H1/CSB328H1/CSB329H1/CSB331H1/CSB340H1/CSB353H1/CSB397Y0

If a student has a concern about the course being synchronous, contact the instructor about other options.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will discuss the genetic and cell biological aspects of the development of gametes, gonads, and sex related traits in animals, including invertebrates and vertebrates. The course consists of lectures and student seminars, and is based on the discussion of primary scientific literature. Not recommended for students with fewer than 14 FCE's.
cmCourseInfo.title: Germ Cell Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

Seminars (50% of the course) will be available only as 'online synchronous' at their scheduled times. 

 

During the Seminars that consists of student presentations and discussions, participation via microphone is essential and mandatory and participation via camera is highly recommended.

cmCourseInfo.description: Gastrulation is used to examine the molecular and cellular mechanisms of a major morphogenetic process and its evolutionary modifications. This course includes small group discussions and presentations. Controversial issues presented in the lectures are debated.
cmCourseInfo.title: Evolution and Development: Gastrulation

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines cellular neurophysiological processes in the developing and mature nervous systems with a focus on: (1) understanding modern techniques used in neurophysiological research; and (2) interpreting the results from neurophysiological peer-reviewed manuscripts. This course is interactive and requires students to contribute actively during lectures and seminars, including conducting a group presentation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Cellular Neurophysiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.content:

Lectures will be held from 2-3 pm and recorded for viewing asynchronously. Tutorials and office hours will be delivered synchronously online from 3-5 pm.

If a student has a concern about the course being synchronous, contact the instructor about other options.

courses.name: Regulatory Networks and Systems in Molecular Biology

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 4, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will expose students to several of the best-understood regulatory networks in molecular biology, as well as recent technological and methodological developments. Emphasis is on the mechanistic basis for these systems, methods and models for quantitative analysis of regulatory networks and the biological logic they encode.
cmCourseInfo.title: Regulatory Networks and Systems in Molecular Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components, and in-person instruction is also planned as an option.  The course instructor will provide details.  In-person learning will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.  In-person learning might require students to bring their own laptop and headset (headphone and microphone).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers theories in why and how we sleep. It will focus on the biological functions of sleep, how the brain generates different sleep states and how breakdowns in sleep mechanisms contribute to sleep disorders like insomnia, sleep walking and narcolepsy. This course emphasizes student participation in seminar discussion and debates.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Sleep Research

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must submit an application form to the CSB Undergraduate Office (RW424) by Monday, 15 June, to be considered with the first round of applicants. Applications will be accepted after this date, but it may take considerably longer to learn your status in the course. Forms are available in the Undergraduate section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca. For more information, please contact the Undergraduate Coordinator, Janet Mannone, at janet.mannone@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. Students will be expected to watch some asynchronous lecture videos prior to online class meetings.  It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Living Without Oxygen: Microbes to Mammals

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth examination of the unique cellular adaptations of different organisms and tissues to survival in low oxygen environments. Cellular, physiological and biochemical strategies, and systemic and whole organism responses will be investigated to uncover broad-ranging common strategies employed by diverse organisms to live without oxygen and in other stressful environments.
cmCourseInfo.title: Living Without Oxygen: Microbes to Mammals

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will be online synchronous only.  No lecture recordings will be provided, but students can record lectures for their own purposes.  It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Molecular Interactions Between Plants, Microorganisms and Parasitic Plants

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the strategies that plants have evolved to defend themselves against microbes and parasitic plants. The course consists of two sections: 1. Plant - pathogenic microbe interactions and 2. Plant - plant parasite interactions. The first section focuses on an in-depth discussion about on-going research of plant immunity against pathogenic microbes. The second section introduces plant - parasitic plant relationships with an emphasis on signalling pathways that underlie these interactions and discusses how basic knowledge of the lifestyle of parasitic plants could contribute to agricultural solutions in the developing world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Interactions Between Plants, Microorganisms and Parasitic Plants

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivered online synchronously. Lectures will be recorded and posted on Quercus after the class. Students can access recorded lectures anytime.

Students’ presentations and the following discussion will also take place online synchronously unless unexpected technical and logistic issues arise.

The mid-term test and final assessment will also be conducted online using the Quercus Quiz function.

Students can have on-line personal meetings with instructors during online office hours or upon requesting an appointment.

The course delivery method is subject to change by unexpected technical or pandemic issues.

cmCourseInfo.description: Microbial pathogens inject effector proteins into host cells in order to sabotage cellular systems and favor the infection process. This course explores the molecular details of how cellular systems (e.g., secretion, cytoskeleton and signaling) are manipulated by pathogenic effectors to promote the infection process, while emphasizing interesting structural and biochemical features of effector biology along the way. The course will also compare and contrast the strategies employed by plant versus animal pathogens, and how immune systems have evolved to cope with cellular hijacking by pathogenic effector molecules. The course will be based on the primary research literature and involve a combination of lectures and critical discussions of research papers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Pathogenic Effector Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be held synchronously online.
Lecture notes will be available online.
Recorded lectures may be available for asynchronous viewing: TBD

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 29, 2020: Room Changed

cmCourseInfo.description: A seminar course exploring non-Mendelian phenomena in plants, fungi and animals that reveal aspects of genome organization and regulation that may provide insight into genome function and evolution.
cmCourseInfo.title: Epigenetics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Most class activities will be online synchronous.  However, recordings of lectures and some class activities will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Detailed delivery information will be provided in the course syllabus.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to major features of gene expression and signal transduction in plants. Topics include strategies for generating transgenic plants and regulating gene expression, as well as the importance of signal transduction in plant growth and survival. How plants sense and respond at the molecular level to environmental stresses such as drought, salinity, cold and disease will be discussed. The application of this basic scientific information in biotechnological strategies for improving agronomic traits will also be addressed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Plant Molecular Biology and Biotechnology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through online synchronous lectures. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities (group presentations). The course instructor will provide details.

cmCourseInfo.description: Plant development, ecological adaptation and crop plant productivity depend on the sophisticated potential of plants to sense and compute signals to regulate their responses. An arsenal of genetic and genomic tools is employed to elucidate these plant signal transduction pathways. Examples from the original literature will be used to introduce general concepts of plant signal transduction, molecular biology and genomics and their application in understanding and influencing plant growth and development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Plant Signal Transduction

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

courses.name: Foundational Discoveries in Genome Biology and Bioinformatics

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is based on the critical analysis of key research articles in genome biology and bioinformatics. The format is interactive and requires students to contribute actively during class meetings. Small student groups will be assigned to present context, figures, data, methods and impact from a number of research articles during the semester. Based on the readings, small student groups will propose new genome technologies or datasets and new bioinformatics software or databases.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundational Discoveries in Genome Biology and Bioinformatics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components, and in-person instruction is also planned as an option.  The course instructor will provide details.  In-person learning will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.  In-person learning might require students to bring their own laptop and headset (headphone and microphone).

cmCourseInfo.description: Computational analyses of DNA and RNA expression data. Understanding biological databases, sequence alignment, sequence annotation, gene prediction, computational analysis of function, motif analysis, phylogenetic analysis, and gene expression profiling analysis. Applied, theoretical and statistical issues will be addressed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Computational Genomics and Bioinformatics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. Lecture recordings will be available for students to view asynchronously, while an interactive lecture discussion will occur synchronously per the course schedule. Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

Students are expected to present a recent "systems biology" paper from a specified list as part of a group. This presentation will take the form of a video recording made available asynchronously to the class, with discussion of it either by online discussion board or during one of the synchronous online classroom sessions, as time permits.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys the field of Chemical Genomics, focusing on the analysis of biological problems using chemical approaches. Topics covered include chemical genetics, combinatorial chemistry and combinatorial strategies in molecular biology. Examines both the underlying biological and chemical concepts; however, the focus is primarily biological.
cmCourseInfo.title: Chemical Genomics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components.  The course instructor will provide details.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to major features of plant metabolism. The content covers plant physiology, natural product chemistry, genetics, molecular biology, and genomics. Topics also include strategies for designing how we modulate metabolic pathways and how we utilize plants for biotechnology through metabolic engineering.
cmCourseInfo.title: Plant Metabolomics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lecture will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 5, 2020: Section cancelled

cmCourseInfo.description: Seminars analyzing major concepts in developmental biology from quantitative, physics-based and molecular perspectives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Development

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The seminar course will be online synchronous, and attendance will be mandatory. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Team-Based Learning: Current Topics in Cell and Molecular Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: A team-based learning course with emphasis on questions in the fields of protein biochemistry, synthetic biology, and the evolution of proteins and networks of protein-protein interactions. Lectures and seminars will focus on current research topics within these fields and will provide the background knowledge for students to work in teams to explore the primary research literature, and for each team to develop a formal research proposal. For details on this year's content, please go to the Undergraduate course section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca.
cmCourseInfo.title: Team-Based Learning: Current Topics in Cell and Molecular Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Most class activities will be online synchronous.  However, recordings of a few lectures and class activities will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Detailed delivery information will be provided in the course syllabus.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Cell and Systems Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: This advanced course covers topics in cell and systems biology at all levels of biological organization. Students learn about the wide array of state-of-the-art molecular, genomic, proteomic, cell biological, imaging, physiological and computational tools and methods that researchers use to study the behaviour of cells.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Cell and Systems Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online synchronous, and attendance will be mandatory. There will also be asynchronous online components.

courses.name: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I

cmCourseInfo.description: An original research project (a literature review alone is not sufficient) requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be mutually agreed upon by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. In the Fall or Winter sessions, a commitment of 8-10 hours per week is expected for research and related course activities. If spread over both the Fall and Winter sessions, a commitment of 4-5 hours per week is expected. In the Summer Session, the number of hours doubles per week (e.g., 16-20 for F or S, or 8-10 for Y) as the length of the term is halved compared to the Fall or Winter term. Many students spend more than this amount of time as they become immersed in their project. This course is normally open only to fourth year students with adequate background in Cell and Systems Biology. Course requirements include a final report, and either an oral presentation (Summer and Fall sessions) or a poster presentation (Winter session). Two workshops on scientific research are scheduled and highly recommended. Details for enrollment are available at the Undergraduate course section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca. Maximum of 2.0 FCEs allowed among CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1. (Lab Materials Fee: $25). Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must submit a completed CSB497H1F contract to the CSB Undergraduate Office (RW424) by Friday, 18 September, before being enrolled. If this is the only course you are taking in 2020-21, the contract must be submitted by Friday, 28 August. Contracts are available in the Undergraduate section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca. Time scheduled is for monthly workshops that are highly recommended. For more information, please contact the Undergraduate Coordinator, Janet Mannone, at janet.mannone@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project.  The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student.  Students are responsible for contacting possible supervisors.  The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components).  In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.  Four workshops are held over the F and S terms for students in CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1, and will be delivered synchronously online.

Currently, it is unclear if in-person research projects will be possible for the F term.  Remote research projects are possible.  Please see the following website for links describing how to find a supervisor and the course enrolment process: https://csb.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-studies/research-opportunities/”
